description: The 3-D Single Point Velocity Meter measures the fluctuating velocity (speed and direction) of water moving past the sensor and platform motion on moving profilers in three-dimensions (u,v,w).
name: 3-D Single Point Velocity Meter

description: Seafloor Pressure sensors measure the force on the seafloor exerted by the weight of the overlying water and atmosphere.  Real-time pressure measurements are of great importance because lunar tides, storms, and tsunamis strongly impact pressures at the seafloor and the flow of fluids into and out of the oceanic crust.
name: Seafloor Pressure

description: Velocity Profiler (short range) uses acoustics to measure 3D water-current velocity for a small volume of the water column above or below the sensor.  The short range sensor is able to measure the current 300 meters or greater from the sensor. High frequency sound waves (75- to 600-kHz) emitted by the profiler scatter off suspended particles and back to the sensor. The sensor calculates velocity by measuring changes in these sound waves (i.e., Doppler shifts). This instrument is also referred to as an Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP).
name: Velocity Profiler (600kHz)

description: pCO2 Water sensors measure the partial pressure of CO2 in seawater.
name: pCO2 Water

description: Seawater pH sensors measure the concentration of hydrogen ions in a solution.
name: Seawater pH

description: An Absorption Spectrophotometer measures optical attenuation and absorption by characterizing the way seawater absorbs and scatters light.  These combined measurements indicate sample turbidity.
name: Spectrophotometer

description: A CTD is so named as it measures Conductivity, Temperature and Depth. These parameters can then be used to calculate salinity and density. CTD Pumped sensors are equipped with a bottom pump used to control flow through the instrument, as well as reduce biofouling.
name: CTD

description: A Dissolved Oxygen sensor measures the concentration of microscopic bubbles of gaseous oxygen that are mixed in seawater (i.e. dissolved oxygen concentration). description: A CTD is so named as it measures Conductivity, Temperature and Depth. These parameters can then be used to calculate salinity and density. CTD Pumped sensors are equipped with a bottom pump used to control flow through the instrument, as well as reduce biofouling.
name: CTD

description: A Dissolved Oxygen sensor measures the concentration of microscopic bubbles of gaseous oxygen that are mixed in seawater (i.e. dissolved oxygen concentration).  The Dissolved Oxygen Stable Response sensor measures dissolved oxygen concentrations on mobile assets, deep profilers, and moorings.
name: Dissolved Oxygen

description: The Digital Still Camera with Strobes is an ethernet camera with strobe lights for capturing high-resolution still imagery of water column biology, vents, diffuse flow, seeps, macrofauna.
name: Digital Still Camera

description: The Bio-acoustic Sonar (Coastal) measures acoustic signals of plankton and zooplankton on coastal arrays.  The sonar emits sound waves into the water column which bounce off organisms back towards the sensor in a phenomenon known as backscatter. The more organisms, the higher the backscatter.
name: Bio-acoustic Sonar (Coastal)

description: Velocity Profiler (short range) uses acoustics to measure 3D water-current velocity for a small volume of the water column above or below the sensor.  The short range sensor is able to measure the current 300 meters or greater from the sensor. High frequency sound waves (75- to 600-kHz) emitted by the profiler scatter off suspended particles and back to the sensor. The sensor calculates velocity by measuring changes in these sound waves (i.e., Doppler shifts). This instrument is also referred to as an Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP).
name: Velocity Profiler (300kHz)

description: The Single Point Velocity Meter measures the mean velocity (speed and direction) of water in two-dimensions (U & V) as it moves past the sensor.
name: Single Point Velocity Meter

description: Seawater pH sensors measure the concentration of hydrogen ions in a solution.
name: Seawater pH

description: Nitrate sensors optically measure the amount of nitrate (NO3-) dissolved in seawater by examining its absorption of ultraviolet (UV) light.  The optical sensor provides fast response measurements, allowing for the sensor to be deployed on profilers, gliders, and AUVs.
name: Nitrate

description: The Spectral Irradiance sensor measures the amount of radiation (light energy) per unit area that reaches a surface.  Radiation is measured and reported separately for a series of wavelength bands, each between 10-20 nm wide.
name: Spectral Irradiance

name: Spectrophotometer

description: A Fluorometer is a device used to measure patterns of fluorescence.  The 3-Wavelength Fluorometer specifically examines chlorophyll-a fluorescence, optical backscatter (red wavelengths), and colored dissolved organic matter (CDOM).
name: 3-Wavelength Fluorometer

description: Velocity Profiler (short range) for mobile assets uses acoustics to measure 3D water-current velocity for a small volume of the water column above or below the sensor. description: A Dissolved Oxygen sensor measures the concentration of microscopic bubbles of gaseous oxygen that are mixed in seawater (i.e. dissolved oxygen concentration).  The Dissolved Oxygen Stable Response sensor measures dissolved oxygen concentrations on mobile assets, deep profilers, and moorings.
name: Dissolved Oxygen

description: A CTD is so named as it measures Conductivity, Temperature and Depth. These parameters can then be used to calculate salinity and density. CTD Profiler sensors are mounted on a profiler.
name: CTD

description: The 3-D Single Point Velocity Meter measures the fluctuating velocity (speed and direction) of water moving past the sensor and platform motion on moving profilers in three-dimensions (u,v,w).
name: 3-D Single Point Velocity Meter

description: Velocity Profiler (long range) uses acoustics to measure 3D water-current velocity for a small volume of the water column above or below the sensor.  The long range sensor is able to measure the current 500 meters or greater from the sensor. High frequency sound waves (75- to 600-kHz) emitted by the profiler scatter off suspended particles and back to the sensor. The sensor calculates velocity by measuring changes in these sound waves (i.e., Doppler shifts). This instrument is also referred to as an Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP).
name: Velocity Profiler (75 kHz)

description: A CTD is so named as it measures Conductivity, Temperature and Depth. These parameters can then be used to calculate salinity and density. description: The 3-D Single Point Velocity Meter measures the fluctuating velocity (speed and direction) of water moving past the sensor and platform motion on moving profilers in three-dimensions (u,v,w).
name: 3-D Single Point Velocity Meter

description: A CTD is so named as it measures Conductivity, Temperature and Depth. These parameters can then be used to calculate salinity and density. description: Velocity Profiler (long range) uses acoustics to measure 3D water-current velocity for a small volume of the water column above or below the sensor.  The long range sensor is able to measure the current 500 meters or greater from the sensor. High frequency sound waves (75- to 600-kHz) emitted by the profiler scatter off suspended particles and back to the sensor. The sensor calculates velocity by measuring changes in these sound waves (i.e., Doppler shifts). This instrument is also referred to as an Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP).
name: Velocity Profiler (75 kHz)

description: The Bio-acoustic Sonar (Global) measures acoustic signals of plankton and zooplankton on global arrays.  The sonar emits sound waves into the water column which bounce off organisms back towards the sensor in a phenomenon known as backscatter. The more organisms, the higher the backscatter.
name: Bio-acoustic Sonar (Global)

description: Velocity Profiler (long range) uses acoustics to measure 3D water-current velocity for a small volume of the water column above or below the sensor.  The long range sensor is able to measure the current 500 meters or greater from the sensor. High frequency sound waves (75- to 600-kHz) emitted by the profiler scatter off suspended particles and back to the sensor. The sensor calculates velocity by measuring changes in these sound waves (i.e., Doppler shifts). This instrument is also referred to as an Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP).
name: Velocity Profiler (75 kHz)

description: A CTD is so named as it measures Conductivity, Temperature and Depth. These parameters can then be used to calculate salinity and density. CTD Mooring (Inductive) sensors are used on surface and subsurface moorings and have the capability of inductive communication with the surface buoy along the mooring riser.

description: The 3-D Single Point Velocity Meter measures the fluctuating velocity (speed and direction) of water moving past the sensor and platform motion on moving profilers in three-dimensions (u,v,w).

description: Velocity Profiler (long range) uses acoustics to measure 3D water-current velocity for a small volume of the water column above or below the sensor.  The long range sensor is able to measure the current 500 meters or greater from the sensor. High frequency sound waves (75- to 600-kHz) emitted by the profiler scatter off suspended particles and back to the sensor. The sensor calculates velocity by measuring changes in these sound waves (i.e., Doppler shifts). This instrument is also referred to as an Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP).
name: Velocity Profiler (75 kHz)

description: Broadband Ocean Bottom Seismometers provide characterization of seismicity/earthquake activity along tectonic plate boundaries where two key phenomena can occur: large-magnitude subduction zone earthquakes and seismicity associated with migration of melt (magma) beneath the seafloor at underwater volcanoes.
name: Broadband Ocean Bottom Seismometer

description: Tidal Seafloor Pressure sensors measure the force of the seafloor exerted by the weight of the overlying water and atmosphere with a focus on tidal pressure changes by measuring pressure shifts down to the millimeter.

description: Broadband Ocean Bottom Seismometers provide characterization of seismicity/earthquake activity along tectonic plate boundaries where two key phenomena can occur: large-magnitude subduction zone earthquakes and seismicity associated with migration of melt (magma) beneath the seafloor at underwater volcanoes.
name: Broadband Ocean Bottom Seismometer

description: Short-Period Ocean Bottom Seismometers detect vibrations from small earthquakes ranging from 0.1 Hz to 100 Hz.  These earthquakes are caused by local phenomena, such as melt movement beneath volcanoes and upward flow of hydrothermal fluids in the conduits that feed black smoker chimneys. These instruments enable imaging of the seismic energy traveling through the seafloor.
name: Short-Period Ocean Bottom Seismometer

name: Velocity Profiler (75 kHz)

description: The Osmosis-Based Water Sampler draws hydrothermal fluids into small capillary-like tubing and allows long-term sampling of diffuse and black smoker hydrothermal fluids, as well as fluids from methane seeps.  Once recovered, laboratory tests examine major/trace element chemistry of the samples.
name: Osmosis-Based Water Sampler

description: Short-Period Ocean Bottom Seismometers detect vibrations from small earthquakes ranging from 0.1 Hz to 100 Hz.  These earthquakes are caused by local phenomena, such as melt movement beneath volcanoes and upward flow of hydrothermal fluids in the conduits that feed black smoker chimneys. These instruments enable imaging of the seismic energy traveling through the seafloor.
name: Short-Period Ocean Bottom Seismometer

description: Short-Period Ocean Bottom Seismometers detect vibrations from small earthquakes ranging from 0.1 Hz to 100 Hz.  These earthquakes are caused by local phenomena, such as melt movement beneath volcanoes and upward flow of hydrothermal fluids in the conduits that feed black smoker chimneys. These instruments enable imaging of the seismic energy traveling through the seafloor.
name: Short-Period Ocean Bottom Seismometer

description: The Diffuse Vent Fluid 3-D Temperature Array measures temperatures of diffuse flow across the seafloor.  The thermister array is designed as 4 stacked triangular arrays with 24 independent temperature measurement points, providing a three-dimensional distribution of temperature.
name: Diffuse Vent Fluid 3-D Temperature Array

description: The HD Digital Video Camera with Strobes captures high definition (HD) video of the seafloor environment that can be used for analytical work. These video cameras feature strobe lights and functions for pan and tilt.
name: HD Digital Video Camera

description: The Horizontal Electric Field, Pressure and Inverted Echo Sounder (HPIES) is an instrument that utilizes a bottom pressure sensor, an inverted echosounder and a horizontal electrometer to provide insights into the vertical structure of current fields, near-bottom water currents, and water properties including temperature, salinity, and specific volume anomalies.
name: Horizontal Electric Field, Pressure and Inverted Echo Sounder

description: A Hydrophone is a passive acoustic sensor that listens for earthquakes, sea creatures, and human-generated noise in the ocean.  The Broadband Acoustic Receiver (Hydrophone) measures the acoustic signal of marine mammals, fish, wind, and rain in the water column.
name: Broadband Acoustic Receiver (Hydrophone)

description: Velocity Profiler (short range) uses acoustics to measure 3D water-current velocity for a small volume of the water column above or below the sensor.  The short range sensor is able to measure the current 300 meters or greater from the sensor. High frequency sound waves (75- to 600-kHz) emitted by the profiler scatter off suspended particles and back to the sensor. The sensor calculates velocity by measuring changes in these sound waves (i.e., Doppler shifts). This instrument is also referred to as an Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP).
name: Velocity Profiler (150kHz)

description: An Absorption Spectrophotometer measures optical attenuation and absorption by characterizing the way seawater absorbs and scatters light.  These combined measurements indicate sample turbidity.
name: Spectrophotometer

description: A CTD is so named as it measures Conductivity, Temperature and Depth. These parameters can then be used to calculate salinity and density. CTD Profiler sensors are mounted on a profiler.
name: CTD

description: A Dissolved Oxygen sensor measures the concentration of microscopic bubbles of gaseous oxygen that are mixed in seawater (i.e. dissolved oxygen concentration).  The Dissolved Oxygen Stable Response sensor measures dissolved oxygen concentrations on mobile assets, deep profilers, and moorings.
name: Dissolved Oxygen

description: A Hydrophone is a passive acoustic sensor that listens for earthquakes, sea creatures, and human-generated noise in the ocean.  The Low Frequency Broadband Acoustic Receiver (Hydrophone) on Seafloor measures acoustic signal of wind, rain, and seismic t-phases on the seafloor.
name: Low Frequency Acoustic Receiver (Hydrophone)

description: Broadband Ocean Bottom Seismometers provide characterization of seismicity/earthquake activity along tectonic plate boundaries where two key phenomena can occur: large-magnitude subduction zone earthquakes and seismicity associated with migration of melt (magma) beneath the seafloor at underwater volcanoes.
name: Broadband Ocean Bottom Seismometer

description: Tidal Seafloor Pressure sensors measure the force of the seafloor exerted by the weight of the overlying water and atmosphere with a focus on tidal pressure changes by measuring pressure shifts down to the millimeter.
name: Tidal Seafloor Pressure

description: The 3-D Single Point Velocity Meter measures the fluctuating velocity (speed and direction) of water moving past the sensor and platform motion on moving profilers in three-dimensions (u,v,w).
name: 3-D Single Point Velocity Meter

description: The 5-Beam, 600 kHz Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (= 50 m range) uses acoustics to measure 3D water-current velocity for a small volume of the water column 50 meters above or below the sensor at resolutions that are appropriate to estimate turbulence parameters. High frequency sound waves emitted by the profiler scatter off suspended particles and back to the sensor. The sensor calculates velocity by measuring changes in these sound waves (i.e., Doppler shifts). This instrument is also referred to as an Acoustic Doppler Current Profiler (ADCP).
name: 5-Beam Velocity Profiler (600 kHz)

description: The Digital Still Camera with Strobes is an ethernet camera with strobe lights for capturing high-resolution still imagery of water column biology, vents, diffuse flow, seeps, macrofauna.
name: Digital Still Camera

description: A Hydrophone is a passive acoustic sensor that listens for earthquakes, sea creatures, and human-generated noise in the ocean.  The Broadband Acoustic Receiver (Hydrophone) measures the acoustic signal of marine mammals, fish, wind, and rain in the water column.
name: Broadband Acoustic Receiver (Hydrophone)

The Dissolved Oxygen Stable Response sensor measures dissolved oxygen concentrations on mobile assets, deep profilers, and moorings.
name: Dissolved Oxygen

description: Seawater pH sensors measure the concentration of hydrogen ions in a solution.
name: Seawater pH

description: A Fluorometer is a device used to measure patterns of fluorescence.  The 2-Wavelength Fluorometer specifically examines chlorophyll-a fluorescence and optical backscatter (red wavelengths).
name: 2-Wavelength Fluorometer

description: A CTD is so named as it measures Conductivity, Temperature and Depth. These parameters can then be used to calculate salinity and density. CTD Profiler sensors are mounted on a profiler.
name: CTD

description: A Dissolved Oxygen sensor measures the concentration of microscopic bubbles of gaseous oxygen that are mixed in seawater (i.e. dissolved oxygen concentration).  The Dissolved Oxygen Fast Response sensor measures dissolved oxygen concentrations on shallow coastal profilers through rapid oxygen gradients.
name: Dissolved Oxygen

description: Seawater pH sensors measure the concentration of hydrogen ions in a solution.
name: Seawater pH

description: A Fluorometer is a device used to measure patterns of fluorescence.  The 3-Wavelength Fluorometer specifically examines chlorophyll-a fluorescence, optical backscatter (red wavelengths), and colored dissolved organic matter (CDOM).
name: 3-Wavelength Fluorometer

description: An Absorption Spectrophotometer measures optical attenuation and absorption by characterizing the way seawater absorbs and scatters light.  These combined measurements indicate sample turbidity.
name: Spectrophotometer

description: A Photosynthetically Available Radiation (PAR) sensor is used to measure the spectral range of light that is available in the water column for use by primary producers for photosynthesis (400-700 nanometers).
name: Photosynthetically Available Radiation

description: The Spectral Irradiance sensor measures the amount of radiation (light energy) per unit area that reaches a surface.  Radiation is measured and reported separately for a series of wavelength bands, each between 10-20 nm wide.
name: Spectral Irradiance

description: Nitrate sensors optically measure the amount of nitrate (NO3-) dissolved in seawater by examining its absorption of ultraviolet (UV) light.  The optical sensor provides fast response measurements, allowing for the sensor to be deployed on profilers, gliders, and AUVs.
name: Nitrate

description: The Single Point Velocity Meter measures the mean velocity (speed and direction) of water in two-dimensions (U & V) as it moves past the sensor.
name: Single Point Velocity Meter

description: pCO2 Water sensors measure the partial pressure of CO2 in seawater.
name: pCO2 Water

description: Bottom Pressure and Tilt sensors are designed to measure the inflation and deflation of the seafloor using a precision pressure sensor that enables detection of the seafloor's rise and fall (i.e., "breathing") as magma (molten rock) moves in and out of underlying magma chambers. A very precise tilt meter (measures in micro-radians) records the "tilting" of the seafloor as it deforms in response to melt migration.
name: Bottom Pressure and Tilt

description: The Mass Spectrometer measures concentrations of dissolved gases such as carbon dioxide, methane, and hydrogen sulfide that are critical to understanding volcanic, chemical, and biological processes in submarine environments.
name: Mass Spectrometer

description: The Particulate DNA Sampler filters a volume of seawater and preserves the particulate matter for genetic analysis of microbial communities after the instrument is recovered.
name: Particulate DNA Sampler

description: The Hydrothermal Vent Fluid Interactive Sampler collects and preserves fluid samples from hydrothermal vents and continuously measures vent fluid temperature.  The sampler is able to be interactive as its connection to the fiber optic cable allows two-way communication and power.  As such, sample bottles can be triggered from shore in response to volcanic or tectonic events or set to trigger at specified intervals.
name: Hydrothermal Vent Fluid Interactive Sampler

description: The Hydrothermal Vent Fluid In-situ Chemistry sensor measures the chemical composition of the mineral-rich fluid plumes that emanate from cracks on the seafloor, providing insight into the sub-surface structure and dynamics of these unique habitats.  Specifically it measures hydrothermal vent fluid temperature, hydrogen, hydrogen sulfide and pH.
name: Hydrothermal Vent Fluid In-situ Chemistry

description: The Hydrothermal Vent Fluid Temperature and Resistivity sensor measures the temperature, resistivity, and eH of the mineral-rich fluid plumes that emanate from cracks on the seafloor, providing insight into the sub-surface structure and dynamics of these unique habitats.
name: Hydrothermal Vent Fluid Temperature and Resistivity
